thig14.1:1.1: Going to the lovely mango grove
thig14.1:1.3: was held up by a rascal.
thig14.1:2.1: “What harm have I done to you,
thig14.1:2.2: that you stand in my way?
thig14.1:2.3: Sir, it’s not proper that a man
thig14.1:2.4: should touch a woman gone forth.
thig14.1:3.1: This training was taught by the Holy One,
thig14.1:3.2: it is a serious matter in my teacher’s instructions.
thig14.1:3.3: I am pure and rid of blemishes,
thig14.1:3.4: so why do you stand in my way?
thig14.1:4.1: One whose mind is sullied against one unsullied;
thig14.1:4.2: one who is lustful against one free of lust;
thig14.1:4.3: unblemished, my heart is freed in every respect,
thig14.1:4.4: so why do you stand in my way?”
thig14.1:5.2: what will going-forth do for you?
thig14.1:5.4: come and play in the blossom grove.
thig14.1:6.1: Everywhere, the scent of pollen wafts sweet,
thig14.1:6.3: The start of spring is a happy time—
thig14.1:6.4: come and play in the blossom grove.
thig14.1:7.2: cry out, as it were, in the breeze.
thig14.1:7.3: But what kind of fun will you have
thig14.1:7.4: if you plunge into the woods all alone?
thig14.1:8.2: and she-elephants aroused by rutting bulls;
thig14.1:8.3: you wish to go without a friend
thig14.1:9.1: Like a shining doll of gold,
thig14.1:9.2: like a nymph wandering in a park of colorful vines,
thig14.1:9.4: in graceful clothes of exquisite muslin.
thig14.1:10.2: if we are to stay in the forest.
thig14.1:10.3: I love no creature more than you,
thig14.1:10.4: O pixie with such bashful eyes.
thig14.1:11.1: Were you to take up my invitation—
thig14.1:11.2: ‘Come, be happy, and live in a house’—
thig14.1:11.3: you’ll stay in a longhouse sheltered from wind;
thig14.1:11.4: let the ladies look to your needs.
thig14.1:12.2: put on your garlands and your cosmetics.
thig14.1:12.3: I’ll make all sorts of adornments for you,
thig14.1:12.4: of gold and gems and pearls.
thig14.1:13.2: its coverlet so clean and nice,
thig14.1:14.1: As a blue lily risen from the water
thig14.1:14.3: so too, O chaste and holy lady,
thig14.1:15.1: “This carcass is full of putrefaction, it swells
thig14.1:15.2: the charnel ground, for its nature is to fall apart.
thig14.1:15.3: What do you think is so essential in it
thig14.1:15.4: that you stare at me so crazily?”
thig14.1:16.1: “Your eyes are like those of a doe,
thig14.1:16.2: or a pixie in the mountains;
thig14.1:16.4: my sensual desire grows all the more.
thig14.1:17.1: Set in your flawless face of golden sheen,
thig14.1:17.2: your eyes compare to a blue lily’s bud;
thig14.1:17.4: my sensual excitement grows all the more.
thig14.1:18.1: Though you may wander far, I’ll still think of you,
thig14.1:18.2: with your lashes so long, and your vision so clear.
thig14.1:18.3: I love no eyes more than yours,
thig14.1:18.4: O pixie with such bashful eyes.”
thig14.1:19.1: “You’re setting out on the wrong road!
thig14.1:19.2: You’re looking to take the moon for your toy!
thig14.1:19.3: You’re trying to leap over Mount Meru!
thig14.1:19.4: You, who are hunting a child of the Buddha!
thig14.1:20.1: For in this world with all its gods,
thig14.1:20.2: there will be no more lust anywhere in me.
thig14.1:20.3: I don’t even know what kind it could be,
thig14.1:20.4: it’s been smashed root and all by the path.
thig14.1:21.1: Cast out like sparks from fiery coals,
thig14.1:21.2: it’s worth no more than a bowl of poison.
thig14.1:21.3: I don’t even see what kind it could be,
thig14.1:21.4: it’s been smashed root and all by the path.
thig14.1:22.1: Well may you try to seduce the type of lady
thig14.1:22.2: who has not reflected on these things,
thig14.1:22.3: or who has never attended the Teacher:
thig14.1:22.4: but *this* is a lady who knows—now you’re in trouble!
thig14.1:23.1: No matter if I am reviled or praised,
thig14.1:23.2: or feel pleasure or pain: I stay mindful.
thig14.1:24.1: I am a disciple of the Holy One,
thig14.1:24.2: riding in the carriage of the eightfold path.
thig14.1:24.3: The dart pulled out, free of defilements,
thig14.1:24.4: I’m happy to have reached an empty place.
thig14.1:25.4: and made to dance in many ways.
thig14.1:26.1: But when the sticks and strings are taken off—
thig14.1:26.4: on what could the mind be fixed?
thig14.1:27.1: That’s what my body is really like,
thig14.1:27.2: without those things it can’t go on.
thig14.1:27.4: on what could the mind be fixed?
thig14.1:28.1: It’s like when you see a mural on a wall,
thig14.1:28.4: falsely perceiving that it is a person.
thig14.1:29.1: Though it’s as worthless as a magic trick,
thig14.1:29.2: or a golden tree seen in a dream,
thig14.1:29.3: you blindly chase what is hollow,
thig14.1:29.4: like a puppet show among the people.
thig14.1:30.1: An eye is just a ball in a socket,
thig14.1:30.2: with a pupil in the middle, and tears,
thig14.1:30.3: and mucus comes from there as well,
thig14.1:30.4: and so different eye-parts are lumped all together.”
thig14.1:31.1: The pretty lady ripped out her eye.
thig14.1:31.2: With no attachment in her mind at all, she said:
thig14.1:31.4: and gave it to the man right then.
thig14.1:32.1: And at that moment he lost his lust,
thig14.1:32.3: “May you be well, O chaste and holy lady;
thig14.1:32.4: such a thing will not happen again.
thig14.1:33.1: Attacking a person such as this
thig14.1:33.2: is like holding on to a blazing fire,
thig14.1:33.4: May you be well, please forgive me.”
thig14.1:34.2: she went to the presence of the excellent Buddha.
thig14.1:34.3: Seeing the one with excellent marks of merit,
thig14.1:34.4: her eye became just as it was before.
